title: Malawi: Exclusive - Malawi Government to Sell Escom
text:
Zimbabwe: Mujuru Fight Personal, About Gossip - Grace Mugabe 
A source within ESCOM, top administration told Malawi24, that Government is planning to sell Nkula and Tedzani Power Plants to United States of America (USA) based companies. 
According to the source, who had been talking to this publication on condition of anonymity, says possible handovers will be done by end this year, with the companies expected to ignite their work early next year. 
Malawi24 understands that the two companies, who are reportedly still in closed meetings with the capital hill, will work differently, one responsible for the production; the second for supplying to users across the nation. 
However, another top official at the power supplying body, argues that most Malawian workers will lose their jobs due to emerging reports that the companies intend to come along with their workers from abroad. 
In the same vein, Malawian will be required to cough more from their chest in settling the bills. 
The amount at which government is selling ESCOM, is yet to be known. 
But when called to comment on the matter, ESCOM's Public Relations Manager, Kitty Chinseu-Chingota told this reporter that she was in a meeting and demanded a questionnaire, but this reporter was racing against newsroom deadlines. 
Reacting to the matter, in an interview with Malawi24 on Friday, Malawi Civil Rights Campaigner Rafiq Hajat said such decisions are due to the mismanagement of tax payers money and public resources. 
Hajat said statutory bodies in the country have dwindled because appointment of incompetent employees. 
"This is primarily due to mismanagement and public appointees to positions that are not qualified in statutory bodies such as Escom and Water board. The way to go on this would be to take on a private management on float. 
"Government should float Escom on stock exchange and make it available to all Malawians to buy shares and not foreigners. This will make every Malawian to have a voice in the running of the company. But they should make sure that it is complying with the needs and expectations of local people. I believe these companies were brought up by tax payers money and should not be digested," Explained Hajat. 
As we went to press, Minister of Natural Resources, Energy and Mining, Paul Chibingu. 
ESCOM, a state owned power producing company is entirely in control of generation, transmission and distribution of electric power in the country. 
According to data on the internet about ESCOM, close to 95% of Malawi's electricity supply is provided by hydropower from a cascaded group of interconnected hydroelectric power plants located on the middle part of Shire River and a mini hydro on the Wovwe River which constitute the interconnected system. 
Total installed capacity of these hydropower plants is 285.82MW (thus 281.5MW for main hydro, and 4.32MW of mini-hydro Wovwe). 
Lately, companies as well as local users in Malawi, have been complaining over unexplained blackouts, which firms said were delaying production. Malawi
